file_content.text: Who are you? What are you doing here?
At last, the great hope of our organization arrives, wading through sparks and metal.
I am Gray Star, my friend. Chemish tells me you're one of the greatest freedom fighters we've had in some time. It's an honor to meet you.
Chemish was wrong about me. I came to Balmorra on a mission to eliminate your cell.
I actually serve the Empire.
It's an honor to meet you, too, sir.
And you.
With those droids destroyed, the Republic will know what's going on. We must move quickly.
This was a tolerable place to hide for a while... but it will be good to be among true allies again.
Now that you're back, what do we do next?
Then what?
We wait for the Empire to become complacent again--it should take only a few days.
Then another strike, of one kind or another. And the Eagle says he may need us again, for his greatest work of all.
What about your own superiors? Is the Eagle a friend to the cause?
"True allies" like the Eagle?
Yes. The Eagle. I met him only once--he came to Balmorra years ago, to learn our methods.
When he began organizing his network, though, I was proud to be associated with him. Together, we will free the galaxy.
I must go to my rendezvous now, and you should not linger--the Republic will level all its firepower against intruders.
You're not going anywhere, Gray Star.
I can't let you leave.
I'm sorry, Gray Star, but I can't let you hurt more people.
You're a danger to innocents.
You. You are a traitor? Or Chemish's messenger is dead.
No more. [Attack]
You can be buried with your "true allies" in a shallow grave.
Actually, you'll be dead.
You threaten me? Then... I was mistaken.
It's time for you to die, you pathetic freak.
Shut up. [Attack]
A traitor, then? One of my own. A pity--but a problem that can be solved.
Come into my cage. I apologize for my guards--the Republic has grown suspicious of me, and the droids watch for mischief.
But it is a pleasure to see a friend--not one of these Republic troopers, but a true friend, able to dream of Balmorra's freedom.
A woman named Chemish sent me here. You know who I'm talking about?
I was ordered to find you.
Yes. A proud and zealous woman. She has great hopes for you.
How did you know I was coming?
You expected me?
I was told by Chemish to expect you. She has great hopes for you.
You have questions, I'm sure. I cannot answer them--but understand that in helping me, you help our organization... as you've done before, and will do again.
I'm proud to have done my part. I'll do anything to set Balmorra free.
Thank you, sir.
Then you will go far, if you are not sacrificed in the struggle.
Can't you at least tell me what you're doing here?
But I need to know things.
I am a Balmorran. I came to the Republic a weary soldier seeking refuge and offering aid--but they do not know my true allegiance.
I didn't come to be inspired. We should get to business.
Let's skip the chat.
We should. Forgive me for enjoying the company.
Now--Chemish said she was sending information. What is it you have?
There's been a change of plans--you're going to rendezvous with one of our people at these coordinates.
You need to meet Sanju.
This is unexpected. I thought Chemish had prepared a safe house--but no matter.
With the droid guardians destroyed, I should be able to escape. It saddens me only a little to leave this home.
It may be some time before we contact you again, but know that we need more recruits like you. More brave soldiers who defy the Empire.
I'll remember that, sir.
You're very kind.
When you get to the rendezvous, give them my regards.
Say "hi" for me.
Enough already. You need to get out of here now.
Just leave.
Goodbye, my friend. Remember--this isn't your fight or the Eagle's fight. This is a fight for our world.
Actually, Chemish--I'm not sure what she wanted. She wasn't really clear... ah, forget it.
I think I lost the message?
You've been tricked, "Gray Star." I'm here for your head.
I have orders to kill you.
I'm not your friend, Gray Star. I'm your enemy.
You're mistaken about me.
I see. Then that changes so much.
Chemish's messenger is dead. Or perhaps you are the messenger, and she never should have trusted you?
You know that even now, my people are arranging the deaths of Imperial collaborators and planting more explosives. Is this your response? Is this your revenge?
You know that even now, my people are arranging the deaths of Imperial collaborators... traitors to Balmorra's cause. Is this your response? Is this revenge?
Even in my prison, you know, I heard about the explosions in Sobrik. The deaths of Imperials. Is this your response? Is this revenge?
This is Imperial justice.
Almost, but not quite.
No. In all the plains and oceans of Balmorra, there is no justice left--only bloodshed.
But remember this: A time will come when the stars dim, the Empire falls, and Balmorra is free once more--no matter what we do today.
Those deaths? I let them happen... all in order to stop you.
This was all a trap.
Then you are a hypocrite as well as a traitor. No culture in history has been able to abide your kind.
You will die now, and you will meet your destiny.
This doesn't have to be about killing. Not if you surrender.
We can end this non-violently.
Thank you, but no. There will be no surrender--not so long as blood is shed over the Balmorran plains.
But remember this: A time will come when the stars dim, the Empire falls, and Balmorra is free once more--no matter what we do today.
So my isolation comes to an end. I wondered how it would happen.
Would the Republic send me to some foreign star for my crimes? Or would the Empire's hunters find me on home soil?
Now I have my answer. Hello, hunter. Join me in my cage.
Are you the man called Gray Star?
What's your name?
This place looks pretty comfortable for a cage.
Your "cage"?
There are no bars, but the effect is the same.
I am Gray Star, leader of the "terror cell" and friend to the Eagle. Trapped by my own arrogance.
I came to the Republic proclaiming myself a weary Balmorran soldier. They took me in, and I led my followers under their oblivious watch. Then they began to suspect.
Did they know about your cell's operations?
How much did they "suspect"?
They believed. They did not know.
You're explaining yourself?
Because I want you to remember that your enemy is not the Republic. It is the Balmorran people.
I can let the Republic kill you instead, then. They can't be happy.
I should leave you to them.
They will not kill me. They have no proof. Besides, the Republic does not execute traitors.
In order to preserve my secrets, I was forced into inaction. So long as the Republic suspected me, I stayed quietly obedient.
I sat and awaited word from my people. I anticipated bombings and reprisals in Sobrik, but there was nothing. I knew my followers were in peril.
I'm the one who prevented the bombings. I stopped your followers.
I'm that "peril."
You're the one? Then you have given me a strange gift.
You assembled a group of killers. You expect me to be sorry?
I can't say I pity you.
I would not expect your sorrow, nor your understanding. And yet... you gave me a strange gift.
Your reign of terror is over. Your "peril" has come home.
Now your end has come.
Perhaps. Yet I thank you for giving me a strange gift.
For so long now, I've lived knowing daily bloodshed. My people attack, the Empire takes its revenge and we attack again.
Briefly, you have ended this cycle. We've killed no one for days, and this brought a small peace. But now, the violence must resume.
What do you mean, "the violence must resume"?
Why?
Can't we stop the violence? We could work together.
It doesn't have to.
You are here to kill me, aren't you? There is no other way for this to end.
I will kill you first, and my cell will recover--or you will kill me first and hunt down my people.
Fair enough.
Then it is time.
Why not come with me? Go willingly into Sobrik, and call an end to it all.
You could surrender.
I could, but what then?
There's a better way.
I was content with the peace. A fleeting thing--gone now, torn away by the winds of war.
How can I abandon my work? How can I abandon my people to the cruelty of the Empire? I have no choice anymore.
Cooperate, and things can improve. The civilian reprisals will stop. There can be limited amnesty for your people.
We can be merciful.
It takes a brave man to change direction. But you can't continue this way.
You must do the right thing!
Perhaps. Perhaps.
You are a creature of the Empire... and yet you brought a measure of peace to our planet. How can I do less?
I will turn myself in. And so long as the Empire does not retaliate against the Balmorran people, I will cooperate with your masters.
It's a fair deal. All right, Gray Star.
Agreed.
It's for the best.
I hope your words are true.
To Sobrik, now, and a destiny I've long sought to escape. How strange the way things end up.
Goodbye, Imperial. I expect we will not meet again.
You turn yourself in and do everything we ask. Nothing else will do.
Not good enough.
Then we can reach no arrangement. Let the tide of peace recede, and the tide of war rise again.
Then I have no choice either.
Very well. [Attack]
The violence ends with your death.
Agreed. [Attack]
It's a pleasure to finally meet you, Gray Star. I'm here to kill you.
Hello and goodbye. [Attack]
Yes, I understand. I will fight back.
But remember this: A time will come when the stars dim, the Empire falls, and Balmorra is free once more--no matter what we do today.
How have you come here?
You thwarted the endless bloodshed; we've killed no one for days, and the Empire takes no revenge. Still, the violence must resume.
It's time I admit the truth.
